case_name: Joint family firm (appellants) v. Bank (respondent No. 1)

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 547 of 1967 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 547 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and decree dated November 14, 1966 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Original Side Appeal No. 9 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated November 14, 1966 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Original Side Appeal. No. 9 of 1959. R. Somnath Iyer, R. K. P. Shankardass, R. V. Ramarao and P.

facts.text: The first respondent Bank filed a suit against the appellants-defendants Nos. 1-4 who are members of the joint family firm for recovery of Rs. 5,00,000/- on the basis of a mortgage deed securing immovable properties without possession.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent Bank filed a suit against the appellants-defendants Nos. 1-4 who are members of the joint family firm, for the recovery of a sum of I.G. Rs. 5,00,000/- on the basis of a mortgage deed executed by them in favour of the Bank by securing certain immovable properties without possession.

facts.text: The first defendant on behalf of the joint family caused the 5th defendant-respondent 2 to guarantee the amount borrowed and executed a promissory note in favour of the 5th defendant on 26-9-1953 for Rs. 5,00,000/- which he endorsed in favour of the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: As a further security, the first defendant on behalf of the joint family, caused the 5th defendant-respondent 2 to guarantee the amount borrowed from the Bank and accordingly he executed a promissory numbere in favour of the 5th defendant on 26-9-1953 for Rs. 5,00,000/- which he in turn endorsed in favour of the Bank.

facts.text: The 5th defendant executed a separate guarantee in favour of the Bank on 26-9-1953.

anchor.surface_text: The 5th defendant also executed a separate guarantee in favour of the said Bank on the same date. As the defendants failed to pay the amounts which fell due under the terms of the mortgage, a suit was filed as aforesaid against all the defendants.

facts.text: Defendants failed to pay the amounts due under the mortgage, leading to the suit.

anchor.surface_text: As the defendants failed to pay the amounts which fell due under the terms of the mortgage, a suit was filed as aforesaid against all the defendants. The 1st defendant who was the manager and Karta of the joint family remained ex- parte.

facts.text: Appellants are admitted to be Jagirdars.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the appellants who it is admitted are Jagirdars had money transactions with the Bank prior to the execution of the mortgage on three separate accounts.

facts.text: Cash credit account opened on 8-8-1953 in the name of the appellant firm with the Bank for Rs. 5,00,000/- secured by mortgage deed Ex. P-10.

anchor.surface_text: It further held that at the request of the appellants they were granted by the first respondent a cash credit to the extent of Rs. 5,00,000/and in companypliance with the terms of sanction the appellants executed a mortgage deed  Ex. P-10  in favour of the Bank that from the fresh cash credit account which was opened on 8-8-1953

facts.text: Amounts due on three prior accounts totaling Rs. 5,00,000/-: Rs. 2,59,436-0-0 on L.B.D. Account; Rs. 2,05,358-8-8 on Overdraft Account Clean Ledger No. 14 Dwarkadas Mukandas; Rs. 35,205-7-4 on Overdraft Account Clean Ledger No. 2 Dwarkadas Mukundas.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt on the evidence held that the amounts due from the appellants on the three old accounts were Rs. 5,00,000/- made up of  a  Rs. 2,59,436-0-0 on the L.B.D. Account  b  Rs. 2,05,358-8-8 on Overdraft Account  Clean  Ledger No. 14  Dwarkadas Mukandas  c  Rs. 35,205-7-4 on Overdraft Account  Clean   Ledger No. 2  Dwarkadas Mukundas.

facts.text: Bank returned thirteen bills duly endorsed to appellants on 8-8-1953 after closing prior accounts.

anchor.surface_text: in the name of the appellant firm with the Bank, the appellants cleared the earlier liabilities under the three accounts mentioned above which were closed and that on the same date the Bank returned to the appellants thirteen bills duly endorsed in favour of the appellant firm.

facts.text: Trial court decreed the suit against appellants and second respondent as first respondent is Scheduled Bank, section 3(v) of Act not applicable, Civil Court has jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts, the trial companyrt held that as the 1st respondent was a Scheduled Bank, the provisions of the Act would number bE applicable by virtue of section 3 v  and accordingly the Civil Court would have jurisdiction to entertain the suit. The suit was, therefore, decreed against the appellants and the second respondent,

facts.text: Original Side Appeal filed in High Court against trial court decree.

anchor.surface_text: against which an original side appeal was filed in the High Court. By the time the appeal came up for hearing, a Full Bench of the Hyderabad High Court

facts.text: High Court confirmed trial court judgment holding debt post-notification (after 30-6-1953), Civil Court has jurisdiction following Full Bench decision.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, following the Full Bench judgment, it was held that the Civil Court had jurisdiction to entertain the suit as the debt was a post-notification debt and in this view companyfirmed the judgment and decree of the trial companyrt.

facts.text: Notified date under section 11 of Hyderabad Jagirdars Debt Settlement Act 1952 is 30th June 1953.

anchor.surface_text: that the suit debts were extinguished under section 22 of the Hyderabad Jagirdars Debt Settlement Act 1952  hereinafter called the Act , inasmuch as numberapplication was presented by the Bank under section 11 of the Act before 30th June 1953 which was the numberified 1 5 9 date

facts.text: 1st defendant remained ex-parte.

anchor.surface_text: The 1st defendant who was the manager and Karta of the joint family remained ex- parte. The 5th defendant though he appeared in the Court, did number file any written statement and chose to remain exparte throughout.

facts.text: 5th defendant appeared but did not file written statement and remained ex-parte.

anchor.surface_text: The 5th defendant though he appeared in the Court, did number file any written statement and chose to remain exparte throughout. Defendants 2-4 alone filed written statements resisting. the suit on several pleas,

facts.text: Defendants 2-4 filed written statements resisting suit claiming debts extinguished under s22 as no s11 application before 30-6-1953 and no jurisdiction under s25.

anchor.surface_text: Defendants 2-4 alone filed written statements resisting. the suit on several pleas, two of which alone may be numbericed for the purposes of this appeal, namely,  i  that the suit debts were extinguished under section 22 of the Hyderabad Jagirdars Debt Settlement Act 1952  hereinafter called the Act , inasmuch as numberapplication was presented by the Bank under section 11 of the Act before 30th June 1953 which was the numberified 1 5 9 date and  ii  the Civil Court had numberjurisdiction to try the suit as under section 25 of the Act all suits and proceedings for the recovery of a debt due from a Jagirdar have to be transferred to the Jagirdars Debt Settlement Board which alone had jurisdiction to settle it.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by certificate against High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is by certificate against the judgment of the Andhra Pradesh High Court which companyfirmed the judgment and decree of a single Judge of the Original Side of that Court.

facts.text: No application under section 11 of the Act was made by the Bank before 30-6-1953.

anchor.surface_text: inasmuch as numberapplication was presented by the Bank under section 11 of the Act before 30th June 1953 which was the numberified 1 5 9 date and  ii  the Civil Court had numberjurisdiction

facts.text: Supreme Court holds mortgage created fresh debt of Rs. 5,00,000/-, prior debts discharged, Civil Court has jurisdiction, confirms decree.

anchor.surface_text: From the terms of this mortgagee it is evident that the debt of Rs. 5,00,0001- is a fresh debt created by and secured thereunder with interest that may become due from the date of the mortgage and that there is, therefore, numberquestion of the mortgage deed having been executed as a settlement of prior debts so as to attract the provisions of sections 1 1 and 25 of the Act. In this view, the Civil Court had jurisdiction and the decree granted by the trial companyrt and companyfirmed by the appellate companyrt does number suffer from any infirmity.

facts.text: No plea raised in trial court or High Court that mortgage lacked consideration or prior debts extinguished affecting mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the fact that both the companyrts on the evidence and on an interpretation of the mortgage deed, held that the mortgage transaction was in respect of a fresh loan advanced to the appellants under that deed, numberplea that the debt was number supported by companysideration or that the earlier debts had been extinguished was either raised before the trial companyrt or before the appellate companyrt.

facts.text: Supreme Court directs appellants to pay half decretal amount within 4 months and balance within 8 months thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly direct the appellants to pay within four months from the date of the judgment half the decretal amount with interest due thereon and the balance thereof together with further interest within 8 months thereafter. If half the decretal amount is number paid within four months as directed, the first respondent will be free to execute the entire decree.

facts.text: Jagirdars' resources affected by abolition of Jagirs by Hyderabad Abolition of Jagirs Regulation 1358 Fasli (1949 A.D.) and Hyderabad Jagirs Commutation Regulation 1359 F (1950 A.D.) passed on 25-1-1950.

anchor.surface_text: Before dealing with the companytentions raised before us, it is necessary to state that as a companysequence of the abolition of Jagirs by the Hyderabad  Abolition of Jagirs Regulation  1358 Fasli  1949 A.D.  and the Hyderabad Jagirs  Commutation Regulation  1359 F  1950 A.D.  passed on 25-1-1950, the re- sources of the Jagirdars were greatly affected

facts.text: Full Bench of Hyderabad High Court in State Bank of Hyderabad v. Mukundas Raja Bhgawandas and Sons held on interpretation of section 25(1) of the Act.

arguments.claim: Section 25 applies only to proceedings pending on notified date for debts where s11 application could be made; s22 extinguishes only such pre debts without s11

anchor.surface_text: A close examination of s. 22 puts the matter beyond controversy. If no application had been made under s. 11 within the period, specified therein or for recording a settlement made under s. 15 every debt due by the debtor was to stand extinguished.

arguments.claim: Civil Court had jurisdiction as mortgage debt not attracting s11 or s25 of Act

anchor.surface_text: In this view, the Civil Court had jurisdiction and the decree granted by the trial court and confirmed by the appellate court does not suffer from any infirmity.

holdings.text: No plea that the mortgage lacked consideration or prior debts were extinguished can be raised for the first time in Supreme Court as not raised below and no issue or ground taken

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the fact that both the courts on the evidence and on an interpretation of the mortgage deed, held that the mortgage transaction was in respect of a fresh loan advanced to the appellants under that deed, no plea that the debt was not supported by consideration or that the earlier debts had been extinguished was either raised before the trial court or before the appellate court. The learned advocate, however, referred us to prayer in para 9 of the written statement in which a plea was taken that the suit is not maintainable and that the plaintiff ought to have submitted its claim before the Debts Settlement Board. This plea is general in character and does-not indicate that the suit is liable to be dismissed as the mortgage is unsupported by consideration. There was also neither an issue in the trial court nor has any ground been taken in the Memo of Appeal though as many as 75 grounds were urged against the judgment of the trial court. We cannot, therefore, permit the appellant to raise any contention based on the mortgage being unenforceable for want of consideration for the first time in this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No plea, issue or ground raised in lower courts; general plea in WS insufficient; appellate practice bars new pleas

holdings.text: The mortgage deed created a fresh debt of Rs. 5,00,000/- secured thereunder with interest from date of mortgage, prior debts discharged from cash credit advance

anchor.surface_text: A perusal of the terms of the mortgage deed clearly justifies the conclusions that the loan of Rs. 5,00,000/- was a fresh debt created by the mortgage deed. There is unimpeachable evidence to show, and this has been accepted by both the courts, that all the three prior debts were paid from out of Rs. 5,00,000/- cash credit loan granted to the appellants under the mortgage deed and the 13 bills of exchange, the time for payment of which had not fallen due and some of which were executed by parties other than the appellants, were endorsed in favour of the appellants and returned to them as a consequence of the discharge of the debts due on the three prior accounts. The mortgage deed states that the properties detailed in schedule annexed thereto were being mortgaged without possession as better security for the repayment of the sum of Rs. 5,00,000/- under the deed together with interest accruing in future and other sums thereby secured.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of deed terms; evidence of prior accounts closure, bills returned, cash credit opened post-discharge

holdings.text: Section 22 extinguishes only debts due on or before notified date under s11 without application; applies only to pre-notification debts and pending proceedings

anchor.surface_text: A close examination of s. 22 puts the matter beyond controversy. If no application had been made under s. 11 within the period, specified therein or for recording a settlement made under s. 15 every debt due by the debtor was to stand extinguished. In a case of the present kind a debt would have stood extinguished if no application had been made under s. 11 within the specified period. Thus the material date would be the one notified by the Government under s. 11 and only those debts which were due on or before that date from a debtor or in respect of which any proceedings were pending in a court or before the Board would be the subject-matter of settlement by the Board.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and harmonious construction of ss11,15,22,25; limits to pre-notification debts

holdings.text: Mortgage not executed as settlement of prior debts so provisions of ss11 and 25 not attracted; Civil Court had jurisdiction; trial court and High Court decree valid

anchor.surface_text: From the terms of this mortgage it is evident that the debt of Rs. 5,00,000/- is a fresh debt created by and secured thereunder with interest that may become due from the date of the mortgage and that there is, therefore, no question of the mortgage deed having been executed as a settlement of prior debts so as to attract the provisions of sections 11 and 25 of the Act. In this view, the Civil Court had jurisdiction and the decree granted by the trial court and confirmed by the appellate court does not suffer from any infirmity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fresh debt post-notification not within Act's scope for extinguishment or transfer; affirms lower courts

directions: Appellants to pay half the decretal amount with interest due thereon within four months from the date of judgment

If half not paid within four months, first respondent free to execute the entire decree

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the fact that both the courts on the evidence and on an interpretation of the mortgage deed, held that the mortgage transaction was in respect of a fresh loan advanced to the appellants under that deed, no plea that the debt was not supported by consideration or that the earlier debts had been extinguished was either raised before the trial court or before the appellate court. The learned advocate, however, referred us to prayer in para 9 of the written statement in which a plea was taken that the suit is not maintainable and that the plaintiff ought to have submitted its claim before the Debts Settlement Board. This plea is general in character and does-not indicate that the suit is liable to be dismissed as the mortgage is unsupported by consideration. There was also neither an issue in the trial court nor has any ground been taken in the Memo of Appeal though as many as 75 grounds were urged against the judgment of the trial court. We cannot, therefore, permit the appellant to raise any contention based on the mortgage being unenforceable for want of consideration for the first time in this Court.
In this view, the Civil Court had jurisdiction and the decree granted by the trial court and confirmed by the appellate court does not suffer from any infirmity.
pending debts within the meaning of s. 25 1 . On this basis, it is companytende

anchor.surface_text: A perusal of the terms of the mortgage deed clearly justifies the conclusions that the loan of Rs. 5,00,000/- was a fresh debt created by the mortgage deed. There is unimpeachable evidence to show, and this has been accepted by both the courts, that all the three prior debts were paid from out of Rs. 5,00,000/- cash credit loan granted to the appellants under the mortgage deed and the 13 bills of exchange, the time for payment of which had not fallen due and some of which were executed by parties other than the appellants, were endorsed in favour of the appellants and returned to them as a consequence of the discharge of the debts due on the three prior accounts. The mortgage deed states that the properties detailed in schedule annexed thereto were being mortgaged without possession as better security for the repayment of the sum of Rs. 5,00,000/- under the deed together with interest accruing in future and other sums thereby secured.
In this view, the Civil Court had jurisdiction and the decree granted by the trial court and confirmed by the appellate court does not suffer from any infirmity.

anchor.surface_text: A close examination of s. 22 puts the matter beyond controversy. If no application had been made under s. 11 within the period, specified therein or for recording a settlement made under s. 15 every debt due by the debtor was to stand extinguished. In a case of the present kind a debt would have stood extinguished if no application had been made under s. 11 within the specified period. Thus the material date would be the one notified by the Government under s. 11 and only those debts which were due on or before that date from a debtor or in respect of which any proceedings were pending in a court or before the Board would be the subject-matter of settlement by the Board.

anchor.surface_text: From the terms of this mortgage it is evident that the debt of Rs. 5,00,000/- is a fresh debt created by and secured thereunder with interest that may become due from the date of the mortgage and that there is, therefore, no question of the mortgage deed having been executed as a settlement of prior debts so as to attract the provisions of sections 11 and 25 of the Act. In this view, the Civil Court had jurisdiction and the decree granted by the trial court and confirmed by the appellate court does not suffer from any infirmity.
In this view, the Civil Court had jurisdiction and the decree granted by the trial court and confirmed by the appellate court does not suffer from any infirmity.
